title.narrative: INTEGRATING CLIMATE CHANGE RISKS IN MALDIVES PROJECT

description.narrative: INTEGRATING CLIMATE CHANGE RISKS INTO RESILIENT ISLAND PLANNING IN THE MALDIVES

title.narrative: 00058332_Integrating Climate Change Risks into Resilient Island Planning in the Maldives_ Pro Doc
Evaluation of the Integrating Climate Change Risks into Resilient Maldives Project
Terminal Evaluation of the Integrating Climate Change Risks into Resilient Maldives Project

description.narrative: Integration of Climate Change Risk into Resilient Island Planning in the Maldives
first-order administrative division
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

To ensure that climate change risks are integrated into resilient island planning in the Maldives and that national provincial atoll and island authorities and communities are able to prioritize and implement climate change adaptation measures
Atoll Development Plans that incorporate climate risk planning and adaptation measures as a result of the project

comment.narrative: Atoll Development Plans do not include climate risk planning and adaptation measures

By the end of the project a comprehensive framework for resilient island planning is being actively used by government authorities to guide decentralized development planning and prioritize climate change adaptation measures across the country

The Project has developed a draft regulation for implementation under the Environment Protection Act that combines the findings of the Climate Risk Resilient Coastal Protection Guidelines and review of land use planning guidelines undertaken by the Project in previous reporting periods This will form the basis for climate risk resilient planning on any coastal developments The draft regulation regulation has been circulated to all relevant Government agencies for comment Focus group discussions were held with relevant key agencies as a formal stakeholder consultation was not supported The second and final draft is being prepared by the Consultants and will be handed over to the Ministry for future implementation
Work on the final requirements of the meteorological database was also undertaken during the reporting period Lack of capacity at the meteorological office has meant that communication regarding certain technical aspects has been difficult and often they are unable to specify requirements in advance This means that when the developers complete a task and present it the meteorological office reviews and requests changes The process has therefore slowed down delivery on the component The project will finalize this component in the coming months to ensure that the Maldives Meteorological Service can provide time series and accurate data that is required for planning purposes
Major strides have been made on the demonstration activities components with contracts awarded for both soft coastal adaptation measures and stormwater management systems Materials were procured during the reporting period Materials were delivered to site for both projects However only the coastal protection in Thinadhoo began physical construction works on the ground during the reporting period

description.narrative: Enhanced capacity of national provincial atoll and island authorities and civil society leaders to integrate climate risk information into policy planning and investment decisions
Number and percentage of national provincialatoll and island planners and decisionmakers trained to evaluate and prioritize climate risks and plan locally appropriate adaptation measures

comment.narrative: National provincialatoll and island authorities have limited knowledge of how to integrate climate risk information into their policies plans and programmes

By the end of the project at least
12 senior decisionmakers and planners from national government including MoF Planning MHA and MHTE
100 of senior decisionmakers and planners in 4 provincesatolls and 4 islands
12 civil society leaders
have been trained to assess and prioritize climate risks and prioritize locally appropriate adaptation measures

In this reporting period additional consultancy was undertaken to integrate some new parameters which the Maldives Meteorological Service had identified after completion of the database and user interface as essential to be maintained within the database system In addition to redesigning the core database structure troubleshooting was also with real time data by the staff trained in the previous reporting period At the end of the reporting period some errors were identified which would need to be corrected Once complete the database will allow the meteorological office staff to efficiently store and retrieve meteorological observation data going back upto 30 years One of the primary objectives of the database is provide ease for the Maldives Meteorological Service to access and provide required data for planning purposes when other Government agencies request it In addition it will speed up the process for the met office to report real time automatically coded data to meet the needs of the World Meteorological Organization and more importantly the International Civil Aviation Organization requirements for aircraft traffic
Funds have been allocated in the 2015 Annual Workplan for the continuation of the training on the economics of climate change adaptation This training session is to be scheduled in the next quarter Two Government participants from the five member country team were supported by the Project in 2014 and will be trained on the next module in 2015
Training delivered by the Project to date
12 participants comprises of 6 central government staff 7 provincial government staff and 1 private sector were trained on current adaptation measures that are prevalent in the country for coastal protection and flood prevention including combinations of soft and hard measures and their costbenefit ratios
16 decision making level Government participants were presented with the results of climate modeling projections and scenarios to integrate climate risk information into planning and policy making processes
18 participants from government staff primarily from the Maldives Meteorological Service were trained on Analysis of Climate Extremes
19 participants including 3 female staff were trained to use the database developed by the Project for the Maldives Meteorological Service

description.narrative: Number of government departments that have integrated climate risk reduction planning into their core work

comment.narrative: Climate risks are not systematically considered in the development and implementation of sector polices and programmes
Climate risk reduction planning has not been integrated into the workplans of staff in MHTE MHA and Department of Planning

Climate risk reduction planning has not been integrated into the workplans of staff in the ministry Project information has however been regularly shared in various workshops and events organized by Ministry and government

description.narrative: Integration of climate risk planning into key national policies that govern or impact land use planning coastal protection and development
Atoll Development Plans that incorporate climate risk planning and adaptation measures as a result of the project

comment.narrative: Atoll Development Plans do not include climate risk planning and adaptation measures
By Year 3 climate risk planning has been integrated into at least 2 key regulations and guidelines including the EIA Regulation and the Guidelines for Land Use Planning

Based on the climate risk resilient coastal protection guideline manual produced by the Project a first draft of amendments to existing regulations such as for EIAs and Land Use Planning were produced in consultation with relevant stakeholders such the Ministry of Housing and Infrastructure and Environment Protection Agency The first draft was circulated and comments received from stakeholders The second draft of the regulation would be produced by October 2015 and will be presented to the Government for further consultation or implementation

description.narrative: Locally prioritized appropriate adaptation options that reduce exposure to climate change risks demonstrated
Atoll Development Plans that incorporate climate risk planning and adaptation measures as a result of the project

comment.narrative: Atoll Development Plans do not include climate risk planning and adaptation measures

By the end of the project at least 50 of households and 50 of critical infrastructure on 4 demonstration islands are better protected from flooding risks as a result of one or more coastal protection measures that have been designed and implemented by the project

0 of households and 0 of critical infrastructure are protected The cost is slightly higher than the available budget of the Project and as the scope of the design cannot be reduced the shortfall of USD 265021 approximately 10 percent has been secured in the 2015 national budget
For the pilot demonstration on stormwater management the Projects designs have been coordinated and integrated into the road development work in Kuldhuffushi island funded by the Government Work is expected to commence in July 2015 Delays are a result of concerns by the Island authorities on the sites that had been previously agreed The objective of this pilot would be to demonstrate climate smart technologies in reducing rainfall induced flooding The infiltration galleries will serve as underground tanks where rainwater from the newly constructed roads will be drained off to during an intense storm These tanks are designed to slowly allow the water to seep back into the ground

description.narrative: Project knowledge and lessons learned compiled analyzed and disseminated locally nationally and internationally
Number of project technical reports information materials and codified lessons communicated through atollprovincial national and international networks and platforms

comment.narrative: The project is yet to generate knowledge good practices and lessons that can be shared

By the end of the project at least one report documenting project experiences and lessons learned produced in different formats for differet target audiences including decisionmakers planners students and island communities with selected reports available in Dhivehi and English

Four knowledge products were designed and prepared for publication Climate Risk Resilient Coastal Protection Guidelines National Climate Change Research Strategy the report on the results of the Climate Downscaling Exercise and the Report on the Adaptation Measures in use in the country The editorial work of these reports has not been completed due to access to required desktop publishing software

title.narrative: LIFE-CYCLE MANAGEMENT SYSTEM OF VESSEL SAFE SHELTERS

description.narrative: Developing a guideline on life-cycle management system of vessel safe shelters in the Maldives.
Establishing Life-Cycle Management of Vessel Safe Shelters in the Maldives
capital of a political entity
seat of a first-order administrative division
seat of a first-order administrative division

The project seeks to strengthen the capacity of the Ministry of Tourism, Arts and Culture and tourism businesses to recognize evident climate risk issues in tourism operations and adopt appropriate adaptation measures to address them.

title.narrative: Quarterly Progress Report 2016 Q1 TAP 60884 Final

description.narrative: Policy Environment for Tourism Adaptation to Climate Change in the Maldives
independent political entity
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

1. Number of tourism related policies strategies and action plans which stimulate investment by tourism operators in climate resilient water, waste, energy and infrastructure management. 2. existance of a platform to promote investment CCA in tourism sector. 3. No of partnership projects with tourist operators and tourism associated communities which reduce their vulnerabilities to climate hazards, initiated 4. No of partnership projects with tourist operators and tourism associated communities which reduce their vulnerabilities to climate hazards, completed
Increase adaptive capacity of the tourism sector in Maldives to respond to the impacts of climate change and invest in appropriate noregrets adaptation measures
Number of tourismrelated policies strategies and action plans which stimulate investment by tourism operators in climate resilient water waste energy and infrastructure management

comment.narrative: Existing tourism policies laws and regulations do not integrate climate risk information and requireenforce private sector investments in climate change adaptation measures
An Addendum to the Maldives National Building Code and its associated compliance documents is developed disseminated and adopted by all tourism resorts

With the recommendation of Ministry of Housing and Infrastructure MoT has plans to incorporate compliance standards based on the Addendum to the MNBC in the Tourism regulations for tourist facilities development
Having provided technical recommendations through the study reports and publications made by the project additional plans are underway for new products which have not been developed This includea developing a strategic plan for Marina Development plan for Maldives which will identify zones and standards for marina incorporating climate change risks
Ministry of Tourism has been given additional responsibilities in overseeing and implementation of environmental impacts assessment EIA for tourism projects As this is a technical area which would require capacity building within the Ministry TAP will be facilitating developing appropriate guidelines and SOPs on this aspect to increase capacity of the Ministry of Tourism

description.narrative: Reduced vulnerability of at least 10 tourism operations and 10 tourismassociated communities to the adverse effects of climate change
Number of tourismrelated policies strategies and action plans which stimulate investment by tourism operators in climate resilient water waste energy and infrastructure management

comment.narrative: Existing tourism policies laws and regulations do not integrate climate risk information and requireenforce private sector investments in climate change adaptation measures

By the end of the project at least 10 tourismassociated communities have planned and implemented concrete adaptation projects which reduce the vulnerability of their infrastructure water waste landuse planning or energy management systems to climaterelated hazards

A total of 13 small grants projects are ongoing by end June 2015 These 13 projects are distributed among 10 Atolls which are R Atoll A Atoll N Atoll Male Atoll ADh Atoll A A Atoll B Atoll L Atoll and G A Atoll Among these 10 atolls there are 11 islands that have ongoing projects
The total amount budgeted for small grants is USD 252500 and USD 39416 has been disbursed The remaining funds are planned for utilization in 2015 USD 185675 and 2016 USD 177589 Additional funds on this activity is planned to be directed to the ongoing grants projects for project enhancement activities depending on the progress

description.narrative: Strengthened adaptive capacity of the tourism sector to reduce risks to climateinduced economic losses
Number of island resorts and tourism operators with increased capacity to reduce risks of climate variability

comment.narrative: Most tourism operators are concerned about their increased vulnerability to climate change but do not draw on or comply with consistent guidance for effective noregrets adaptation measures to increase resilience

By the end of the project 100 of relevant MTAC staff and at least 60 of all trained tourism operators recognize the economic impacts of climate change on tourism operations and know the costbenefit aspects of different adaptation investments

Training conducted in Climate risk financing solutions The conference ended on 5th June 2015
Training for MoTMTAC staff on climate adaptation was held on 12th February 2015 All sections of the ministry participated including 17 male and 30 female staff
Training for Trainers consultancy underway for educators Training will commence in August 2015 in 5 atolls including school teachers and councilors The training is to be conducted based on Climate Change Adaptation and Environment Monitoring on Tourism Dependent Communities
A presentation was made by TAP Project Manager in the opening Session of the Regional Tourism Ministers Conference organized by the Ministry of Tourism and World Tourism Organization UNWTO held in Bandos Island Resort on 3rd June 2015 The Conference was attended by HEP the President Mr Yameen Abdul Gayyoom the Secretary General of UNWTO Dr Taleb Rifai Cabinet Ministers and Head of Independent Insttutions and Officials of the government of Maldives Asia and the Pacific Ministers among UNWTO member states and participants of the Regional Commission meetings of the UNWTO A total of 152 delegates comprising of 116 foreign delegates and 36 local delegates participated in the conference opening session

description.narrative: Number of new investment projects in the tourism industry that are designed and implemented in accordance with revised tourism policies and planning frameworks

comment.narrative:
National policies and laws regulating tourism operations do not contain functional references to climateproofing and fail to
incentivise private sector investment in climate risk management
By the end of the project an Addendum to the Maldives National Building Code and its associated compliance documents is developed disseminated and adopted by all new tourism development projects
None However the addendum and compliance documents will be incorporated in the tourism regulations and awareness programmes are planned for year 2016

description.narrative: Transfer of climate risk financing solutions to public and private sector tourism institutions
Number of staff from government agencies and tourism operators who have increased knowledge of climate risk financing instruments

comment.narrative: Government entities and tourism sector operators in Maldives have limited knowledge of climate risk financing products and their potential application in the Maldivian context

At project completion all representatives in relevant MTAC MEE MHI departments and all representatives of different tourist facility groups including resorts safari boats and hotel operators are aware of climate risk financing and transfer instruments and their potential in the Maldivian context

A feasibility study on indexbased insurance and risk polling options Activity 32 and feasibility study on microinsurance for tourism associated communities to buffer climate related shocks from extreme events Activity 33 have been completed and Training Sessions have been conducted with private sector private sectoe local councils and all the existing insurance companies operating in the Maldives
Training sessions have been completed in the 4th quarter of 2014 as reported in the previous reporting period Furthermore 2 pilot project proposals were developed in consultation with stake holders attended by private sector and the public sector including the insurance companies working in the Maldives

description.narrative: Increasing climate resilience through an Integrated Water Resource Managment programme in 3 Islands

title.narrative: Evaluation of the Integrated Water Resources Management Project

description.narrative: The primary problem addressed by this project is a significant climate change induced decline freshwater security that is affecting vulnerable communities in Maldives
capital of a political entity
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

1. Progress towards completion of Integrated Water Resource Management Systems in HA. Ihavandhoo, ADh. Mahibadhoo and GDh. Gadhdhoo 2. Ihavandhoo, ADh. Mahibadhoo, and GDh. Gadhdhoo who have uninterrupted access to reliable and safe freshwater supply in extreme climatic conditions

1. Integrated Water Resource Management Systems completed and handover to Utilities companies in Ihavandhoo, Mahibadhoo, and Gadhdhoo 2. 0 3. 100%
1- Integrated Water Resource Management Systems completed and handover to Utilities companies in Ihavandhoo, Mahibadhoo, and Gadhdhoo 2- 0 3. 100%
1. Integrated Water Resource Management Systems in HA. Ihavandhoo, ADh. Mahibadhoo and GDh. Gadhdhoo are functioning and defects rectification 2. 30 3. 100%

title.narrative: HCFC PHASE-OUT MANAGEMENT PLAN FOR MALDIVES

description.narrative: HCFC PHASE-OUT MANAGEMENT PLAN FOR MALDIVES
HCFC Phase-out Management Plan for Maldives ‚Äì UNDP Component: [MDV/PHA/60/INV/20]
capital of a political entity

The programme will assist the Laamu Atoll and its islands to realize low emission and climate resilient development (LECReD). The programme seeks to mainstream LECReD issues into local level development planning
Project to support low emission climate resilient local development in Maldives. It will achieve this by taking an atoll-based approach, focusing on Laamu Atoll
